The positive control in both parts was 64 mg/kg cyclophosphamide with sacrifice at 24 hr. In the first part, a total of 7 females died at the high dose. In the second part, one female died at 1125 mg/kg within the 24 hr period. There was no treatment-related increase in micronuclei formation with any sacrifice time or dose. ...

non_human_toxicity_excerpts.References: Loprieno N et al; Mutat Res 74 (3): 250 (1980)
non_human_toxicity_excerpts.Value: /GENOTOXICITY/ Investigations demonstrate that atrazine is activated by plant enzymes to produce a mutagenic metabolite for Schizosaccharomyces pombe (forward mutation) and Chinese hamster cells (forward mutation). Atrazine is positive in the host mediated assay (mouse, yeast injected intrasanguineously) and induced chromosome aberrations in bone marrow cells of mice after single dose of 1 g/kg and 2 g/kg, respectively.

/GENOTOXICITY/ Assays for dominant lethal mutations, nondisjunction, and loss of chromosome were conducted on male Drosophila melanogaster treated by injection or by larval feeding of atrazine. It significantly increased the rate of dominant lethals, but this reduction in the hatchability of eggs was probably due to the physiologic toxicity to sperm. Atrazine increased X linked recessive lethals and X or Y loss after treatment by larval feeding. No significant increase in partial loss of the Y chromosome or sex chromosome nondisjunction was observed.

/GENOTOXICITY/ The genotoxic activity of atrazine, a widely used triazine herbicide, was assayed by the DNA alkaline elution technique in rats given orally a single high dose or repeated daily doses. DNA breaks (and/or alkali-labile lesions) were detected in cell suspensions obtained from stomach, kidney and liver, but not in those from lung.

/GENOTOXICITY/ ... Atrazine ... did not induce point mutations or mitotic recombinations. Even the S9 mammalian metabolic activation system was unable to genetically activate /this/ compound. ... /In strains of Salmonella typhimurium used included TA-97a, TA-98, TA-100, TA-1535, TA-1537, and TA-1538./

/GENOTOXICITY/ The herbicides... atrazine and trifluralin were tested for genotoxicity in the mouse bone-marrow micronucleus test (MNT). Both atrazine and trifluraline caused a significant increase in the number of micronuclei at doses of 1,400 mg/kg body weight in female mice only...

/GENOTOXICITY/ A commercial preparation of atrazine /was/ tested on a diploid D7 strain of the yeast Saccharomyces cerevisiae using cells from logarithmic growth phase (with a high level of cytochrome P-450) and from stationary growth phase. The compound induced marked increases of both gene conversion and point mutation frequencies in the logarithmic phase cells, while in the stationary phase no genotoxic effect was observed. The results obtained employing TA98 and TA100 strains of Salmonella typhimurium (Ames test) confirmed that atrazine /was not/  mutagenic.  ... The in vivo effects on cytochrome P-450 content (Cyt.P-450) and on monooxygenase activities were examined in hepatic microsomes of induced animals (rat, pig, and rabbit) 24 hrs after acute treatment. The results obtained with atrazine showed that it caused different effects in the three animal species.

/ALTERNATIVE and IN VITRO TESTS/ This study sought to determine the impact of in vitro exposure to the herbicide atrazine (ATR) or its major mammalian metabolite diaminochlorotriazine (DACT) on dopaminergic cell differentiation. N27 dopaminergic cells were exposed for 24 or 48 hr to ATR or DACT (12-300 uM) and their effects on cell viability, ATP levels, ADP:ATP ratio and differentiation markers, such as soma size and neurite outgrowth, were assessed. Overall, intracellular ATP levels and soma size (decreased by ATR at >/=12 uM; 48 hr) were the two parameters most sensitive to ATR exposure in undifferentiated and differentiating dopaminergic cells, respectively. At the morphological level, ATR, but not DACT, increased the percentage of morphologically abnormal undifferentiated N27 cells. On the other hand, exposure to DACT (300 uM; 48 hr), but not ATR, increased the ADP:ATP ratio regardless of the differentiation state and it moderately disrupted thin neurite outgrowth. Only the highest concentration of ATR or DACT (300 uM) was cytotoxic after a longer exposure (48 hr) and undifferentiated N27 cells were the least sensitive to the cytotoxic effects of ATR or DACT. Our results suggest that the energy perturbation and morphological disruption of dopaminergic neuronal differentiation induced by ATR and, to a lesser extent, DACT, may be associated with reported neurological deficits caused by developmental ATR exposure in rodents.

/ALTERNATIVE and IN VITRO TESTS/ Atrazine (ATR) is a broad-spectrum triazine herbicide that disrupts steroidogenesis resulting in reproductive and developmental toxicity at high doses. Mouse BLTK1 Leydig cells were used as a steroidogenic model to investigate the effects of ATR on testosterone (T) biosynthesis. Induction of steroidogenesis by 3 ng/mL recombinant human chorionic gonadotropin (rhCG) induced intracellular 3',5' cyclic adenosine monophosphate (cAMP) approximately 20-fold and T approximately 3-fold at 4 hr. Co-treatment with 300 uM ATR super-induced cAMP levels 100-fold yet antagonized rhCG-mediated induction of T approximately 20% at 4 hr. ATR inhibited cAMP-specific phosphodiesterase (cPDE) with an IC50 of >/= 98 uM, suggesting cPDE inhibition contributes to the super-induction of cAMP. However, concentrations of up to 3 mM db-cAMP did not antagonize rhCG induction of T levels, suggesting cAMP super-induction alone does not decrease T biosynthesis. Western analysis of cAMP-activated protein kinase A (PKA) target proteins identified ATR-mediated concentration-dependent alterations in phosphorylation including phospho-CREB. These results suggest the cPDE inhibition by ATR and super-induction of cAMP are independent of effects on T levels, and that altered phosphorylation of key steroidogenic regulatory proteins may underlie ATR-mediated disruption of steroidogenesis.

/ALTERNATIVE and IN VITRO TESTS/ The effects of s-triazine derived herbicides and a number of polycyclic chlorinated hydrocarbon pesticides on soya seed and bovine heart lactate-dehydrogenase activity were investigated in vitro. Dialyzed and lyophilized preparations of the two enzymes were used for the inhibition experiments. Enzyme activity was measured spectrophotometrically as the rate of loss of nicotinamide adenine dinucleotide from a reaction mixture containing sodium pyruvate, phosphate buffer and an nicotinamide adenine dinucleotide solution. The reaction was started by adding an enzyme solution. Pesticides were added at various concentrations. From measurement of the dependence of the reaction rate on the nicotinamide adenine dinucleotide concentration at a constant saturation concentration of pyruvate, the inhibition constant was calculated for each pesticide. Eight chlorotriazines were used at concentrations of 0.16 or 0.33 mmol: atrazine, trietazine, terbutylazine, norazine, ipazine, chlorazine, propazine, and simazine. All but propazine and simazine inhibited bovine heart lactate-dehydrogenase, producing inhibition contants from 1.5 mmol for atrazine to 2.3 mmol for ipazine. The activity of the plant lactate-dehydrogenase was inhibited by atrazine (inhibition constant 3.7 mmol) and trietazine (inhibition constant 5.4 mmol). The methoxytriazines and methylthiotriazines, ametryne, desmetryne, atratone, and noratrone inhibited the reaction catalyzed by plant or animal enzymes with respect to the nicotinamide adenine dinucleotide coenzyme. Inhibitor concentrations were 0.66, 1.60, 2.50, and 3.30 mmol, respectively. Inhibition constants for bovine heart lactate-dehydrogenase were 6.5, 3.6, 71.0, and 44 mmol; for soya seed lactate-dehydrogenase for the same four compounds, inhibition constants were: 4.1, 7.5, 77.0, and 82.0 mmol.

/ALTERNATIVE and IN VITRO TESTS/ Preconfluent cultures of normal rat intestinal cells (IEC-6 cell line) and normal human colonic epithelial cells were treated with 0.05-50 muM doses of atrazine, diazinon, and endosulfan. After 3 days of treatment, the change in cell proliferation was quantified by cell counting or the MTT growth assay. Both intestinal and colonic epithelial cell cultures had increases in cell growth when treated with as little as 1.0 uM atrazine, diazinon, or endosulfan. The observed changes in both cultured intestinal and colonic cell growth rates were not due to the influence of the vehicle control dimethyl sulfoxide (DMSO). That is, the treatment of the cell cultures with concentrations of dimethyl sulfoxide as high as 0.5% for 3 days resulted in no change in cell growth compared with untreated control cultures. A consistent observation with all three of the compounds was that the highest doses (50 uM) had the least "proliferative potential" in stimulating either IEC-6 cell or human colonic epithelial cell growth. Within the concentration range used, none of the herbicides or pesticides caused a decrease in cell proliferation below that of the untreated control cultures. Overall, treatment of IEC-6 cell cultures with atrazine, diazinon, or endosulfan produced a biphasic growth response, whereas the same treatment in the human colonic epithelial cell cultures produced a more sustained level of growth over the same period.

/ALTERNATIVE and IN VITRO TESTS/ Atrazine is one of the most widely employed herbicides. Due to its environmental persistence, it can be detected in ground and water thus becoming the subject of a serious concern because of its potential endocrine disrupting activity. In particular, several in vitro and in vivo studies point out adverse effects on reproduction. However, these data were mainly collected in the male, while studies on females are lacking. Present work was therefore set up on swine ovarian granulosa cells to investigate the effect of atrazine on steroidogenesis and proliferation. Moreover, since vessel growth is fundamental for reproductive function, ... the herbicide's effect on two of the main angiogenesis signaling molecules, VEGF and NO /was examined/. ...Data show that atrazine markedly interferes with steroidogenesis while it does not modify cell proliferation; in addition, the herbicide has also been found to affect the production of the examined angiogenesis molecules. Collectively, these results indicate for the first time a potential negative effect of atrazine on ovarian functions in the swine species.

non_human_toxicity_excerpts.References: Fierro R et al; Biol Reprod 112 (2004)
non_human_toxicity_excerpts.Value: /ALTERNATIVE and IN VITRO TESTS/ ...The aim of this study was to investigate the effect of the herbicides atrazine and fenoxaprop-ethyl on the viability, capacitation and acrosomal reaction of porcine spermatozoa. The CL(50) /European for LC50/, CL(50/2) and CL(50/5) concentrations of both herbicides were tested. The spermatozoa were incubated with the herbicides during 4 and 4.5 hours (capacitated and reacted, respectively) at 39 °C in a humid atmosphere and 5% CO2. The acrosomal reaction was induced by adding progesterone during the last half hour of incubation. The negative control was under the same conditions, with no herbicides. Capacitation and acrosomal reaction were evaluated using the chlortetracycline stain and viability using the eosin-nigrosine stain. The experiments were done at least three times. Control values were considered as 100%. Sperm viability with both herbicides decreased significantly as concentration was increased. The CL50 for atrazine was 40 uM and for fenoxaprop-ethyl was 60 uM. Results demonstrate that both herbicides increased the capacitated and acrosome-reacted spermatozoa respect to the control. The action of atrazine begin at 8 uM, the capacitated spermatozoa increased to 152-155% and reacted to 153-172% as dose increased, but it was not concentration dependant. The fenoxaprop-ethyl increased capacitation to 189-279% and acrosomal reaction to 143-200%, clearly presenting a concentration-response effect. Both compounds showed significant differences when compared to the negative control.

/IMMUNOTOXICITY/ The present study was designed to investigate the immunotoxicity of atrazine (ATZ) in male Balb/c mice. ATZ (175, 87.5, and 43.75 mg/kg bw/day) was administered by gavage method for 28 days. The following indexes were determined in various groups of mice: body and organ weight; antibody aggregation of serum hemolysin; proliferative response of splenocytes to ConA; delayed-type hypersensitivity (DTH); natural killer cell activity; clearance of neutral red and nitric oxide (NO) release from peritoneal macrophages; apostosis and necrosis of splenocytes and thymocytes; cytokine production; and serum lysozyme. Results showed that cell-mediated, humoral immunity, and non-specific immune function in the high-dose ATZ group were suppressed; NO release and interferon-gamma (IFN-gamma)/interleukin-4 (IL-4) were also significantly decreased in the high-dose group. In the medium-dose group, the proliferation response and IFN-gamma production was significantly decreased. In the low-dose group, the proliferation response was significantly decreased. Serum lysozyme was decreased in the ATZ-treated groups. The percentage of early apoptosis in thymocytes was increased significantly in high- and medium-dose ATZ groups. In conclusion, ATZ elicited an inhibitory effect on cell-mediated immunity, humoral immunity, and non-specific immune function of mice.

non_human_toxicity_excerpts.Value: /VETERINARY STUDIES/ Acutely poisoned sheep and cattle exhibited muscular spasms, fasciculations, stiff gait and  increased respiratory rates. Adrenal degeneration and congestion of lung, liver and kidneys were  observed.

/OTHER TOXICITY INFORMATION/ Bacteria are present extensively in the environment. Investigation of their antioxidant properties will be useful for further study on atrazine stress tolerance of bacteria and the defense mechanism of antioxidant enzymes against atrazine or other triazine herbicides. Superoxide dismutase (SOD), catalase (CAT), glutathione S-transferase (GST) and total antioxidant capacity (T-AOC) from one Gram-negative representative strain Escherichia coli K12 and one Gram-positive representative strain Bacillus subtilis B19, respectively, were tested for response to atrazine stress. The results indicated that SOD, CAT, GST and T-AOC were induced upon exposure to atrazine. The growth of two bacteria was better in the absence than in the presence of atrazine, indicating that atrazine can decrease bacterial growth. The changes of enzyme activities indicate the presence of oxidative stress. Oxidative stress induced by atrazine may be due to imbalance of redox potential in bacterial cells, which leads to bacterial metabolic disorder.

Atrazine concentrations in sediments collected from the Danube and Traun Rivers in Austria were 0.44-0.64 ug/kg(2). The concentration of atrazine was determined in sediments of 5 salt marsh sites on the Essex, UK coast at <0.1-43.3 ng/g(3). Atrazine was detected 11 times in a monitoring study of sediment samples collected from 27 stations in south Florida canals between Nov 1991 and June 1995, the highest concentration was 50 ug/kg(4). The concentration of atrazine in sediments collected from the Ebro delta, Spain, the Thermaikos Gulf, Greece, the Amvrakikos Gulf, Greece and the Nile delta, Egypt were reported as 0.015-0.070, <0.02-4.9, 0.8-2.4, and <0.001 ug/g dry weight, respectively(5).

SSSA Spec Pub No. 32 (1994) (3) Koskinen WC, Rochette EA; Intern J Environ Anal Chem 65: 223-30 (1996) (4) Weber JB; Appl Plant Sci 5: 29-41 (1991) (5) Ahmad R, Rahman A; J Agric Food Chem 57: 10866-75 (2009) (6) Bedmar F et al; Weed Technol 18:1-8 (2004) (7) Bernard H et al; J Environ Qual 34: 534-43 (2005) (8) Krutz LJ et al J Agric Food Chem 51: 7379-84 (2003) (9) Swann RL et al; Res Rev 85: 23 (1983) (10) Meakins N et al; Marine Pollut Bull 30: 812-19 (1995)
soil_absorption_mobility.Value: The Koc of atrazine in loamy soil, calcareous clay, and high clay was determined to be 109.9, 80.0, and 88.9, respectively(1). The Koc values for atrazine in four Hawaii soils were 54-150 mL/g(2). The Koc of atrazine in a Zimmerman fine sand, a Verndale sandy loam and a Waukegan silt loam, each with 9.6% water content, was determined to be 1164, 775 and 936, respectively(3). The Koc of atrazine in Norfolk, Rion, Cape Fear and Webster soils was determined to be 150-200, 84, 202, and 166, respectively(4). Atrazine had a reported mean Koc of 126.9 (range of 26 to 821) in 101 allophanic and non-allophanic surface soil samples collected throughout New Zealand(5). Koc values of atrazine for three regions of Argentina were reported as 77-161(6). Koc values of two soils from Reunion Island, France were reported as 97 and 117(7). Atrazine had measured Koc values of 88 in vegetated filter strip soil (37.9% sand, 31.9% silt, 30.2% clay, 4.2% organic carbon, pH 7.6) and 92 in cultivated soil (36.8% sand, 29.5% silt, 33.7% clay, 2.5% organic carbon, pH 7.6)(8). According to a classification scheme(9), these Koc values suggest that atrazine is expected to have very high to slight mobility in soil, depending upon soil type(SRC). The Koc range for atrazine in salt marsh sediment was 64-546.3, with 59.2-91.8% of atrazine adsorbed to sediment(10).

soil_absorption_mobility.References: (1) Gamble DS, Khan SU; J Agric Food Chem 38: 297-308 (1990) (2) Gamble DS, Khan SU; Can J Chem 70: 1597-1603 (1992) (3) Albanis TA et al; Toxicol Environ Chem 19: 171-78 (1989) (4) Calvet R; Environ Health Perspect 83: 145-77 (1989) (5) Fruhstorfer P et al; Sci Tot Environ 138: 317-28 (1993) (6) Kalouskova N; J Environ Sci Health 24: 599-617 (1989) (7) Ma L, Selim HM; Rev Environ Contam Toxicol 145: 129-73 (1996) (8) Seta AK, Karathanasis AD; Soil Sci Am J 61: 612-17 (1997) (9) Lin CH et al; J Environ Qual 32: 1992-2000 (2003)
soil_absorption_mobility.Value: The rate constant for sorption and desorption of atrazine by organic soil at 25 °C was determined to be 5.02X10-2/day (half-life = 13.8 days) for sorption and 0.1507/day (half-life = 4.6 days) for desorption(1). Atrazine sorption half-life ranged from 3.6 to 735 days and desorption half-life ranged from 1 to 11 days in slurries of a mineralized soil(2). An addition of fly ash up to 0.5% in a sandy clay loam results in decreased adsorption of atrazine by 7.3% on the avg; the same amount of fly ash in clay soil decreases atrazine adsorption by 6.5%(3). The adsorption of atrazine by aluminum montmorillonite was 0.37 mole/g at pH 6.0, by aluminum montmorillonite + sodium hydroxide was 2.70 mole/g at pH 7.4, and by aluminum hydroxide was 0.50 mole/g at pH 6.2; the adsorption of atrazine by iron montmorillonite was 0.94 mole/g at pH 4.6, by iron montmorillonite + sodium hydroxide was 1.50 mole/g at pH 5.7, and by iron hydroxide was 0.32 mole/g at pH 7.5(4). At an initial concentration of 100 ug/L atrazine, the amount of atrazine adsorbed by montmorillonite at pH 4.5 and pH 9.5 was determined to be 4.4 and 1.65 ug/L, respectively; the amount of atrazine adsorbed by kaolinite at pH 4.5 and pH 9.5 was determined to be 0.02 and 0.03 ug/L, respectively(5). The rate constant for the adsorption of atrazine on humic acid at 20 °C and pH 2.5 to 6.2 ranged from 1.8X10-5 to 7.2X10-1; the amount of atrazine adsorbed by humic acid within 24 hours decreased with increase in pH with no adsorption observed above pH 5.5(6). Atrazine adsorption is higher at lower soil pH and reaches maximum adsorption when surface acidity is approximately equal to the dissociation constant; soil organic matter has the highest adsorption affinity to atrazine among soil constituents: in a study of a Webster soil, organic matter contributed to 68% of atrazine adsorption(7). In a soil column study, the presence of colloids enhanced the transport of atrazine by 2 to 18%, depending upon colloid type and mobility; colloids with higher pH, total exchangeable bases, cation-exchange capacity, organic carbon, surface area, and electrophoretic mobility showed greater mobility, greater affinity for atrazine, and greater potential to co-transport atrazine; in contrast, increased levels of kaolinite, iron, and aluminum inhibited atrazine adsorption and transport(8). In fields with varying ground covers (bare ground, orchard grass, tall fescue, timothy, smooth bromegrass, switch grass) treated with atrazine, leach concentrations ranged from 2.52 to 5.87% of applied amount over 25 days with six rain events(9).

plant_translocations.content: The study investigates the potential uptake and accumulation of acetochlor and atrazine in wheat plants, as well as their mechanisms of uptake, translocation, and subcellular distribution. Hydroponic experiments were conducted using a concentration of 10 mg L−1 for both herbicides. The findings indicate that acetochlor is taken up by wheat roots through the apoplastic pathway and primarily accumulates in the roots with limited upward translocation. In contrast, atrazine is taken up by roots through the symplastic pathway and subsequently transported to the stems and leaves. The preferential distribution of acetochlor in root organelles with higher lipid contents restricts its upward translocation, while atrazine exhibits easier upward translocation due to its low bioconcentration in root organelles and cell walls. The partition-limited model effectively predicts the uptake of acetochlor and atrazine by wheat roots and the distribution of atrazine to the stems and leaves. The results highlight the potential risk to the safety of wheat crops posed by residual atrazine in soil, as it can be taken up by wheat roots and acropetally translocated.
plant_translocations.reference: Ju, C., Zhang, H., Wu, R., Dong, S., Yao, S., Wang, F., ... & Yu, Y. (2020). Upward translocation of acetochlor and atrazine in wheat plants depends on their distribution in roots. Science of the total environment, 703, 135636.

method.Apply Location: Roots of wheat seedlings immersed just below the surface of the solution
method.Plant Grown Condition: Seeds were disinfected with a 5% sodium hypochlorite solution for 15 min, washed three times with sterile water, soaked in sterile water for 16 h, and germinated for 5 days in seedling trays with sterile moist filter paper. Seedlings were then transferred to sterile glass containers with sterile nutrient solution for continued growth for 1 week in a growth chamber with a light intensity of 250 µmol m-2s-1, light from 05:00 to 21:00, and a temperature of 25/20°C light/darkness with a relative humidity of 70%.
method.Chemical Preparation: atrazine (98.5%) were used. The nominal concentration of both in the exposure solution was 10 mg/L, lower than their solubility in water but high enough to ensure approximate saturated uptake by wheat roots.
method.Pesticide Application Details for the Pl: Twenty-five seedlings were transplanted into separate sterile glass containers with 1.5 L exposure solution containing acetochlor or atrazine at a concentration of 10 mg/L. Containers without herbicides were used as controls to monitor the possibility of cross-contamination, whereas containers without a seedling were used as unplanted controls to monitor herbicide loss in the absence of seedlings.
method.Other Information: All treatments consisted of three replicates.

plant_translocations.content: This study focuses on analyzing the effects of long-term atrazine exposure on the aquatic macrophyte Typha latifolia (cattail) and characterizing the morphological changes, uptake, translocation, and bioaccumulation patterns of atrazine and its biodegradation metabolites (desethylatrazine and desisopropylatrazine) in the plant tissues. The cattail plants were subjected to hydroponic exposure to 20 μg/L atrazine for varying durations. The findings reveal reductions in plant weight and transpiration, indicating chronic phytotoxicity. Atrazine was detected in different plant tissues, with higher concentrations observed in the leaves, sprouts, and upper leaf sections. The metabolites DEA and DIA were found at similar concentrations in submerged tissues, with DIA being the predominant metabolite in the leaves. The study suggests that atrazine uptake occurs from the roots to the shoots, but the phytotoxic effects reduce its translocation to the shoots. Additionally, Typha latifolia demonstrates the potential ability to biodegrade atrazine through various metabolic pathways.
plant_translocations.reference: Pérez, D. J., Doucette, W. J., & Moore, M. T. (2022). Atrazine uptake, translocation, bioaccumulation and biodegradation in cattail (Typha latifolia) as a function of exposure time. Chemosphere, 287, 132104.

method.Plant Grown Condition: Grown in greenhouse conditions with a natural summer photoperiod, a mean temperature of 28.33 ± 8.28°C, and a mean relative humidity of 41.20 ± 14.52%
method.Chemical Preparation: Atrazine standard (>95%) was purchased from Sigma-Aldrich, and the isotopically labeled version (atrazine-d5) was purchased from CDN Isotopes. Methanol, acetone, ethyl acetate, hexane, formic acid, acetonitrile (HPLC grade)
method.Pesticide Application Details for the Pl: A stock solution with a concentration of 2000 mg/L of atrazine was prepared using methanol. A single dose of this stock solution, measuring 37.8 μL, was added to each treated container, resulting in an initial nominal exposure concentration of 20 μg/L.
method.Other Information: Plants were supported by a 15-cm-thick closed-cell foam seal and shielded from light with aluminum foil. Daytime photosynthetic photon flux averaged ~850 μmol m-2 s-1. Young plants were grown in a vegetative nutrient solution under aerobic conditions for two weeks before atrazine exposure. Root zone samples were filtered through a 0.22-μm nylon filter and analyzed using LC-MS/MS.

plant_translocations.content: Barley plants were exposed to six herbicides and a systemic fungicide (four triazines, diuron, 2,4-dichlorophenoxyacetic acid (2,4-D), and ethirimol). The relationships between uptake and transpiration rate were discussed in the light of the physico-chemical properties of these compounds, notably their partition coefficients in oil/water systems and their dissociation constants. Apart from 2,4-D, sorption of these compounds appears to be a passive process. At pH 4, the uptake of 2,4-D seems to be influenced by metabolism; not only may the concentration of this compound in the transpiration stream be considerably greater than that in the medium surrounding the roots, but absorption by roots is markedly reduced at low temperatures and by sodium azide. The initial rate of uptake of these compounds correlates reasonably well with their partition coefficients in olive oil/water or ra-dodecane/water systems; likewise, the concentration in the transpiration stream is greater for lipophilic than for lipophobic substances. The hydrogen ion and calcium concentrations of the ambient medium appear to have no effect on the uptake of compounds with low pK's, but the uptake of those substances which protonate between pH 4 and pH 6 is affected by them. These findings are discussed from the viewpoint that the pathways of transport of lipophilic and lipophobic compounds across the roots may differ.
plant_translocations.reference: Shone, M. G. T., & WOOD, A. V. (1974). A comparison of the uptake and translocation of some organic herbicides and a systemic fungicide by barley: I. Absorption in eelation to physico-chemical properties. Journal of experimental botany, 25(2), 390-400.

method.Test Plant: One-week-old barley plants (Hordeum vulgare var. Proctor)
method.Plant Growth Condition: Solution culture conditions not explicitly described. Previous methods referenced (Shone and Wood, 1972a).
method.Chemical Preparation: Simazine, atrazine (ring-14C labeled), atratone (prepared from atrazine), hydroxyatrazine (prepared from atrazine method of Castelfranco et al. 1961), diuron (14C-carbonyl labeled), ethirimol (ring-14C labeled), 2,4-D (side chain-14C labeled, diluted to 5-25 μCi/mg). Concentrations ~10^-6 M or 5x10^-7 M in solution.
method.Pesticide Application Details for the Pl: The compounds were applied to the barley plants in solution, with concentrations ranging from 0.1 to 0.2 parts per million (ppm) or approximately 10^-6 to 5x10^-7 M, unless otherwise specified.

plant_translocations.content: The absorption and translocation of atrazine and linuron were studied in carrot, parsnip, lettuce, and turnip seedlings. Significant differences were observed among species in herbicide distribution within the plants. Carrot and parsnip seedlings retained a high proportion of absorbed linuron in their root systems, while lettuce and turnip translocated over 60% of absorbed linuron to the shoot. With atrazine, differences among species were less pronounced. The amount of herbicide translocated correlated with the amount of water transpired by the plants, but the effective concentrations in the transpiration stream were lower than in the treatment solutions. Thin-layer chromatography of plant extracts revealed that up to 45% of translocated linuron in parsnip and carrot was metabolized, while little metabolism occurred in the shoots of lettuce and turnip or in the roots of any species. These findings suggest that parsnip and carrot seedlings' tolerance to linuron is due to a combination of root fixation and metabolism in the shoot.
plant_translocations.reference: Walker, A., & Featherstone, R. M. (1973). Absorption and translocation of atrazine and linuron by plants with implications concerning linuron selectivity. Journal of experimental botany, 24(2), 450-458.

method.Test Plant: Carrot (Daucus carota L. cv. Chantenay), parsnip (Pastinaca sativa L. cv. Syaton Intermediate), turnip (Brassica rapa L. sub-sp. rapa cv. Golden Ball), and lettuce (Lactuca sativa L. cv. Borough Wonder)
method.Apply Location: Root application by suspending seedlings in nutrient solution containing the herbicides.
method.Plant Grown Condition: Seeds were germinated in moist sand and seedlings with two true leaves were transferred to 50 ml Hewitt's nutrient solution in boiling tubes.
method.Chemical Preparation: 14C-carbonyl-labeled linuron (specific activity 6.85 μCi/mg) and 14C-ring-labeled atrazine (specific activity 10-22 μCi/mg) were used at 0.05 μg/ml concentration in nutrient solution.
method.Pesticide Application Details for the Pl: 15 seedlings of each species were transferred to fresh nutrient solutions containing the respective 14C-labeled herbicides.
method.Other Information: Plants were harvested at 3, 5, 7, 10 and 12 days after treatment with 3 replicates per species per herbicide at each harvest.
